Someone shapes the meta by slipping through bans and if Yasuo was ever allowed to be in mid lane we wouldn't see half the champs that are in that lane. Yasuo has the problem of a contradictory kit. He has a strong early game to help him kick off. But he doesn't really fall off late game compared to most early game champs. He counters ranged champs, but at the same time can out duel melee champs due to his defensive stats and mobility. So he is supposed to counter range champs. Yet he gets free tank shred making him also good at killing everyone else (even better now that armor is getting more abundant). His kit is more overloaded than Lee's and people complain about Lee.

A generalist pick is actually fine - the problem is when he outperforms or can compete with specialists in their own niche.
AFAIK a generalist should be a "jack of all trades, master of none", someone who you can safely first pick and expect to be ok-ish with.
Imho the problem with Lee is the same Yasuo has, and that is one of agency - you beat him only if he screws up, because he's simply too good at too many things if played correctly.

The ease with which they can screw up keeps them balanced, but not actually having agency against them is very frustrating.

To be honest, having strong generalists isn't an issue on its own. The issue arises when the specialists aren't strong enough nor have a distinct enough yet relevant enough niche to compete ...

I think DOTA is a good example. Every patch you have a handful of heroes that picked extremely often due to the fact that they fit in practically every team comp. However, you'll still see almost every other hero picked as well, either because they fit or round out their team comp's strength so much more, or because they just have a better match up vs. the enemy heroes. Hell, a hero is usually _not_ picked due to actually being too weak for the patch or just not fitting in the meta at all.
